headline: Sen. Joe Manchin: I hope Trump's tax reforms work
subHeadline: Democratic West Virginia senator discusses tax policy on 'Your World.'

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOE MANCHIN, D-WEST VIRGINIA
utterances.sentences: No, no. Here's what I -- I'm hoping it works. I'm hoping I'm wrong, Neil. I really am.  Neil, all I have is history to work off of. I worked off of Ronald Reagan, who we all loved, Democrats and Republicans loved. We worked off of Ronald Reagan. He started in '84. He got something done, three volumes that Jim Baker did, by '86. We had everything to look through. We opened it up. And they started with revenue-neutral.  Now, we all know what happened after that, Neil. Things were wonderful. It was great. But he started with revenue-neutral. And by the time we got to 1990, '91, "Read my lips, no new taxes," George H. Bush had to fall on the sword because the economy dipped and started changing. And then he had to some raise taxes to keep the country afloat. That's what his...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, you might -- you're right. That might happen, Senator.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But the fact of the matter is, we have all of these companies doing this now.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And I'm wondering if you are concerned that you or some of your Democratic colleagues might not have appreciated that? Certainly even the White House has admitted that it couldn't have fathomed all these companies sharing the loot to the degree they are.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Sure.  Here's the thing, Neil. I'm the first to tell you that when -- if I make a decision, I have got to make it on what I have in front of me and based on historical values that I have had to refer on.   So you have that one, and then on top of that one the mandate, when they repealed the mandate, when we had a fix without -- with a bipartisan fix. I'm thinking, try the fix before you repeal it. If it doesn't work, then do what you have to do in repealing it. Rather going down $1.5 trillion down to 21 percent, could we have stopped at 25 percent, permanently at 25 percent, waiting three years, see if the GDP kept growing, see if the debt started going down?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Then go further.  So, Neil, here. Of all that being said, that's how I made my decision as a no vote. I'm a Democrat who is willing to work any way I can, because there's going to be a lot of repairs needed, and I will be there to help make those repairs. I'm not one saying, oh, I told you so.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, so I just want to be clear, because now Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein, a big supporter of Hillary Clinton, has said that he thinks that Donald Trump is driving this economy.  We're also hearing Jamie Dimon over at J.P. Morgan Chase saying, because of these tax cuts, he thinks it's going to produce 4 percent growth. If that pans out, you have just paid for the tax cuts.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: If it pans out for 10 years, thank God. If it doesn't pan out, go look at your children and grandchildren and thank them, because they will be paying for it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The concern about the deficits. I know this has been a big issue for you.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But it seems to ring hollow when I hear a lot of Democrats in particular, sir, talk about deficits and debt that piled up under Barack Obama. They piled up under a lot of presidents of all sorts, I will grant you.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: That's hypocrisy, hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But do you worry now that this could be a game-changer?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: I don't worry at all. I hope it is.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: I'm here saying how I think that I owe my constituents all over my state, why did I make my decision? I just explained to you. That's exactly why I made my decision.   I thought we could have worked. If it would have failed, we could have sat down and worked through some -- I think some more moderate, OK?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Got it.  Then let me ask you to switch gears a little bit.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I understand your view there. And we're pressed for time.  But I did want to get your views as well on what is going to be done on immigration.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: We're going to fix it. We have got to fix it now.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, but Chuck Schumer has already taken off the table the commitment to funding a wall that was on the table. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: We're going to build a wall. Here, that's all rhetoric, OK? Chuck will make a deal. He will make it happen. He -- nobody wants these children -- I don't have many in my state, so it's not a pressing issue in the state of West Virginia. But I have a heart, and I'm sympathetic, and I have empathy for these...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, but he took the wall off the table. Have you?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Well, he did not. OK?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, he did. The funding for that, he said he's not going to do.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Well, let me tell you one thing. We need to have border security, Neil. I'm voting for border security. There's other Democrats who will vote for border security. We have got to repair some of the wall that we have. We have got to build some new wall. We need technology. We need border agents. We need a port of entry. We need our mail, all of mail being scanned for fentanyl coming in. We need the northern border protected. We're going to protect the border.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, this funding for a wall that he's now done a 180 on, I just want to be clear. And I understand what you're saying, Senator. Does that mean he's left open these things that you just mentioned?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think it's all rhetoric right now, the wall.  The president has said he wants a wall. First of all, if we didn't need a wall, I would say, well, that's not right because the experts tell me we don't need it. We do need a wall. In certain places, we need a wall. And I think the president has acknowledged that.  Chuck will come around. He will call it border security. Someone will call it a wall. Whatever it is, we're going to do it. We're going to do what it takes to secure our country, I can assure you. I'm going to vote for that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, sir, but we're pressed for time.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You have mentioned the wall. This meeting at the White House with mayors, a couple opted out, including New York's Bill de Blasio, because of the Justice Department's crackdown or proposed crackdown on sanctuary cities like New York. And most of the mayors still went to this thing with the president. But what do you think of that? And do you think that Bill de Blasio is wrong not going to this event with the president today on this one issue?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Any time the president of the United States says, would you come and talk to me, and an American citizen who loves our country won't do that because of your politics, you might be in it for the wrong reason.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, on this issue of sanctuary cities...

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: You should go talk.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Where do you stand?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: I have not been for sanctuary cities. It's not, again, a pressing issue in West Virginia. But if we had an immigration policy that worked for our country, you wouldn't be talking about sanctuary cities. But I have not been supportive. I have not voted to support sanctuary cities. But I can see people coming from that part that think that, hey, they're going to fight for whatever they think is right. I can respect that. I don't have to agree with them.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: I think we need -- here, Neil, we wouldn't be having this conversation if we would had the House of Delegates vote on the 2013 immigration bill. It was one of the toughest, one of the best border bills we ever had, security bills. It was one of the toughest pathways and get rid of all the illegals who came here for the wrong reason. But no one wants to go back there again, but we should.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But I'm wondering if we're going to have another shutdown threat in just a couple of weeks.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: No, we're not going shut down. If they shut down again, they're crazier than I believe that everyone has gotten in this place.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you criticized the leadership on both sides for having too much influence in driving this.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Both sides.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: What do you want to see?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: First of all, I'm going to say this. I have been here for, what, since November of 2011. The place has never worked the way people told me it did. Not the way Bob Byrd told me it did. The place has never worked. Two people shouldn't have this kind of power. Now, I'm not blaming Mitch or Chuck. It happened to be what it is. But we, as senators, have got to take it back and make the Senate work. They shouldn't decide what goes on and when it goes on. And the majority leader has that discretion. And the minority leader says, we're going to stop and slow this down. Let's work together. And that means that this bipartisan group that we have, which is the common cause -- commonsense coalition, Susan Collins and myself, we're going to meet again tomorrow morning. We're going to continue to push, 25 or 30 of us, saying, listen, you're not going to lead us around like sheep. That's not who we are. I'm going to fight for West Virginia. I'm going to make sure West Virginia is heard. And, by golly, we're going to do this the right way.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, Senator, thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All these breaking news and developments. Always appreciate it, sir. END Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. And then he had to some raise taxes to keep the country afloat. That's what his...

utterances.utterance: All right, so I just want to be clear, because now Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein, a big supporter of Hillary Clinton, has said that he thinks that Donald Trump is driving this economy. utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: If it pans out for 10 years, thank God. If it doesn't pan out, go look at your children and grandchildren and thank them, because they will be paying for it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The concern about the deficits. I know this has been a big issue for you.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But it seems to ring hollow when I hear a lot of Democrats in particular, sir, talk about deficits and debt that piled up under Barack Obama. They piled up under a lot of presidents of all sorts, I will grant you.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: That's hypocrisy, hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But do you worry now that this could be a game-changer?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: I don't worry at all. I hope it is.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: I'm here saying how I think that I owe my constituents all over my state, why did I make my decision? I just explained to you. That's exactly why I made my decision. I thought we could have worked. If it would have failed, we could have sat down and worked through some -- I think some more moderate, OK?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Got it. Then let me ask you to switch gears a little bit.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I understand your view there. And we're pressed for time. But I did want to get your views as well on what is going to be done on immigration.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: We're going to fix it. We have got to fix it now.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, but Chuck Schumer has already taken off the table the commitment to funding a wall that was on the table. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: We're going to build a wall. Here, that's all rhetoric, OK? Chuck will make a deal. He will make it happen. He -- nobody wants these children -- I don't have many in my state, so it's not a pressing issue in the state of West Virginia. But I have a heart, and I'm sympathetic, and I have empathy for these...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but he took the wall off the table. Have you?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Well, he did not. OK?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, he did. The funding for that, he said he's not going to do.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Well, let me tell you one thing. We need to have border security, Neil. I'm voting for border security. There's other Democrats who will vote for border security. We have got to repair some of the wall that we have. We have got to build some new wall. We need technology. We need border agents. We need a port of entry. We need our mail, all of mail being scanned for fentanyl coming in. We need the northern border protected. We're going to protect the border.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, this funding for a wall that he's now done a 180 on, I just want to be clear. And I understand what you're saying, Senator. Does that mean he's left open these things that you just mentioned?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think it's all rhetoric right now, the wall. The president has said he wants a wall. First of all, if we didn't need a wall, I would say, well, that's not right because the experts tell me we don't need it. We do need a wall. In certain places, we need a wall. And I think the president has acknowledged that. Chuck will come around. He will call it border security. Someone will call it a wall. Whatever it is, we're going to do it. We're going to do what it takes to secure our country, I can assure you. I'm going to vote for that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry, sir, but we're pressed for time.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You have mentioned the wall. This meeting at the White House with mayors, a couple opted out, including New York's Bill de Blasio, because of the Justice Department's crackdown or proposed crackdown on sanctuary cities like New York. And most of the mayors still went to this thing with the president. But what do you think of that? And do you think that Bill de Blasio is wrong not going to this event with the president today on this one issue?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Any time the president of the United States says, would you come and talk to me, and an American citizen who loves our country won't do that because of your politics, you might be in it for the wrong reason.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, on this issue of sanctuary cities...

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: You should go talk.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Where do you stand?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: I have not been for sanctuary cities. It's not, again, a pressing issue in West Virginia. But if we had an immigration policy that worked for our country, you wouldn't be talking about sanctuary cities. But I have not been supportive. I have not voted to support sanctuary cities. But I can see people coming from that part that think that, hey, they're going to fight for whatever they think is right. I can respect that. I don't have to agree with them.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: I think we need -- here, Neil, we wouldn't be having this conversation if we would had the House of Delegates vote on the 2013 immigration bill. It was one of the toughest, one of the best border bills we ever had, security bills. It was one of the toughest pathways and get rid of all the illegals who came here for the wrong reason. But no one wants to go back there again, but we should.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But I'm wondering if we're going to have another shutdown threat in just a couple of weeks.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: No, we're not going shut down. If they shut down again, they're crazier than I believe that everyone has gotten in this place.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you criticized the leadership on both sides for having too much influence in driving this.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Both sides.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you want to see?

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: First of all, I'm going to say this. I have been here for, what, since November of 2011. The place has never worked the way people told me it did. Not the way Bob Byrd told me it did. The place has never worked. Two people shouldn't have this kind of power. Now, I'm not blaming Mitch or Chuck. It happened to be what it is. But we, as senators, have got to take it back and make the Senate work. They shouldn't decide what goes on and when it goes on. And the majority leader has that discretion. And the minority leader says, we're going to stop and slow this down. Let's work together. And that means that this bipartisan group that we have, which is the common cause -- commonsense coalition, Susan Collins and myself, we're going to meet again tomorrow morning. We're going to continue to push, 25 or 30 of us, saying, listen, you're not going to lead us around like sheep. That's not who we are. I'm going to fight for West Virginia. I'm going to make sure West Virginia is heard. And, by golly, we're going to do this the right way.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, Senator, thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: MANCHIN
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Neil. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All these breaking news and developments. Always appreciate it, sir. END Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
